titleInfo.title: The correspondence of Athanasius Kircher [electronic resource] : the world of a seventeenth century Jesuit : an international research project / Michael John Gorman and Nick Wilding

mods.abstract: "The Athanasius Kircher correspondence project was created with the goal of making the manuscript correspondence of Athanasius Kircher available on the Internet. The project was commenced through the collaboration of the Istituto e Museo di Storia della Scienza in Florence, the Pontifical Gregorian University in Rome and the European University Institute in Fiesole, under the direction of Michael John Gorman and Nick Wilding. Since September 2000, the project has been rehoused at Stanford University." -- Introduction.

location.physicalLocation: Archives of the Pontifical Gregorian University, APUG 568

Translations of these riddles have been carried out by Dr. Sebastian Brock (who has provided this information on the document), and will shortly be available to users."

titleInfo.title: Aimé Chézaud to Kircher
Apollonius of Perga, Conics, beginning of Book V (in Arabic)

relatedItem.abstract: This text has been identified by Jan Hogendijk, of the University of Utrecht, who suggests that it is the revision of al-Isfahani or al-Shirazi brought to Europe from Constantinople by Christianus Ravius and exhibited to various scholars in Holland between 1642 and 1647 . Only books I to IV of the Conics survived in Greek, and were first translated in an edition by Giovanni-Battista Memmo at Venice in 1537. This edition, which contained many errors, was replaced by Federico Commandino's translation, published in Bologna in 1566. Various versions of books V-VII in Arabic circulated in Europe during the seventeenth century. In 1629, Jacobus Golius brought a Codex of the Conics to Leiden, and planned to publish a translation of the lost books. In the 1640s the English mathematician John Pell worked on a translation of another manuscript of the Conics, brought back from Constantinople by Christian Ravius. Information from Apollonius Conics Books V to VII: The Arabic Translation of the Lost Greek Original in the Version of the Banu Musa, edited with translation and commentary by G.J. Toomer, New York: Springer-Verlag, 1990, vol. 1, xx-xxv, and Fuat Sezgin, Geschichte des Arabischen Schrifttums, Leiden: Brill, 1974, Band V, p. 141"

Information about this record has been provided by Charles Burnett."
